I love all of your videos including this one! I love seeing your faces.
>>just wanted to mention I've been watching for 6 years!

Also, as someone who does yoga I just wanted to say that in my experience that yes, yoga can hurt you. But you're going to know that you're hurting yourself. Either you push a stretch much too hard or you fall and get unlucky. In 11 years of doing yoga I have only hurt myself one time, and that's because my son jumped on me while I was doing a weird pose.

It does really help with alot of things including posture, sleep, energy, and mindful eating (I actually didn't realize that was a benefit until I watched this video, but I thought about it and it's true).
In my opinion....Everyone who's physically capable, should do at least 10 minutes of yoga every day. It's just so good for you. And you'll probably want to do more than that once you start doing it anyways.

I really enojyed this format. It shows how science is present in our lives even in the most unexpected ways. Also, I'm very fond of using scientific studies to make better decisions in our lives, so I felt very contemplated.
I think the ideia is awesome and you certainly can use it in many different scenarios where it might fit better. Such as:
- Coffee "paradigm" (I know you already made 2 or three whiteboard videos about it, but it's still a very controversy thing as new studies keep coming up)
- 5 second rule - There are a lot of studies on microorganisms in our house, so not just this famous rule but other things such as bacteris in the kitchen-sponges, cleaning the toilet seat before seating etc
- Sports benefits
- Anything at all because science is everywhere

I don't think it should ever replace the white-board format, but could totally became a secondary thing in the channel.

You trash are confused!!

Real Yoga is more like Qigong, which is "spiritual breathing", or, cultivation of breath.

Real Yoga (much like meditation) is the use of breath as means to anchor and cultivate the mind, which in turn augments the body, as it is mastery of breath that leads to mastery of metabolism.

Yes the asnas are supposed to indirectly teach you about the way to alter breathing toward the aim of obtaining the benefits of self mastery, but asanas are not required for Yogic expansion of consciousness.
All you need for the path of self-mastery, is cultivation of breath and its correlating concentration of mind which leads to heightened awareness of whatever your attention is directed at, in or through.
Towards the aim of refining self-mastery, routine exercise is beneficial too, but not "a must", if your diet and sleep pasterns are in correct balance.

Yoga is not just yoga there are many primary schools and I once lost about 50 pounds on Ashtanga yoga. Doing Iyengar would probably never show the same results not to mention Hatha.

I did a yoga course in grade 11. I have an overly sedentary lifestyle, but this was first period. It helped wake me up and we always focussed on form an injury prevention before learning new moves. I also discovered that it's difficult to treat yoga as one thing because some yoga is highly intesitive and structured more like a HIIT, while others are supposed to encrease muscle endurance. Then of course, there is full on restorative which is very calming, especially for a highschool student with approaching exams

In my opinion most yoga injuries happen when a person has lost awareness of their spinal alignment during the yoga. With conscious breathing and spinal awareness a person is well aware how to move in order to marry the effort with ease. And not to push into postures that are not unfolding like a flower blooming. Its so much more mental and spiritual than physical.
